Processing and P5.JS

I got into the whole Processing universe through a few generative art courses on Skillshare. If you don‚Äôt know yet, Processing is a Java library (I believe there is a Python library too) that makes drawing and creating both fixed and animated digital art very easy. To get started, you need only to download the IDE and fill out a few methods, which could look as simple as:

of course, you can build out and develop as complex art as you want, like these examples.

Motivation for this Data Challenge

So, after learning the very basics about Processing and working through a few examples on Skillshare, I started exploring other‚Äôs work, also mostly on Skillshare. The videogame nerd that I am, I took a particular liking to the ‚ÄòInvaders‚Äô work by Jerome Herr‚Äôs 2013 work. I then saw he was originally inspired by Jared Tarbell who appears to be the first to do work and provided a fractal implementation of Invader generation.

That‚Äôs when I saw my chance to put my own spin on Invaders. Both Jerome‚Äôs and Jared‚Äôs works were not determinant. In otherwords, each time you run their respective programs, you get a different result. With my more application and web minded background, I saw that all the Invader data could first be generated, and then loaded at any later time. And so this Data Challenge!TM began!

I started by diving into the code kindly provided by Jerome, but then I started getting frusterated with the Java syntax entirely. It‚Äôs been over 10 years since I wrote any Java, and that was my Junior year in Highschool‚Ä¶ so yeah, I was looking for (hopefully) a Javascript possibility. And what do you know, there is a JavaScript library for processing!

It just so happens that completely by chance, the very cover animation on the home page of my blog, which you may or may not know depending on how often you visit the blog, is a p5.js animation! I didn‚Äôt make the connection at first because I originally found that library through this ‚ÄòShow HN‚Äô post showcasing the library back at the end of August, 2018, and that ‚Äòcircles bouncing around in a container‚Äô example is a pretty generic example which I just lightly refactored for my site. Plus, the names P5 and Processing just never connected in my mind!

So I finally bit the bullet and said, alright, I wanna do this in JavaScript, let‚Äôs convert this Java code to Javascript. Cuz, cmon, who doesn‚Äôt do things in Javascript these days? üòÇ (Yes, a bit of sarcasm, but honestly‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs been fairly true - we‚Äôll see what happens in 2019) Anyway, the REAL reason I wanted to do it in Javascript was to get more practice with p5.js. I‚Äôll likely be using in the future for even more projects!

The Scaffolding

I also wanted to build this site with react. Then of course, because p5.js uses canvas elements, you need a wrapper to pass events to it from react and blah blah blah. Yay, state-of-the-web in 2019!

Luckily, there is a boilerplate repository by atorov with not one but two examples of how to use p5.js sketches with react!

Math and Data Generation

The math behind Invader generation is lightly discussed directly on the Invaders page, but I‚Äôll go into detail here.

A helpful analogy for me was to picture this array of 15 as 15 switches next to eachother, each being switch on or off at random, until you have every possible combination. In simplist terms, this can be realized as a binary list of length 15.

I‚Äôll admit, I struggled with how to do this correctly in Python. I jumped immediately to the itertools library, trying to work some magic with permutations and/or combinations, but Python kept thinking it should count each 0 in the list as unique, so I kept getting what I considered ‚Äòrepeat‚Äô entries, for example: ‚Äò100000000000000‚Äô and ‚Äò10000000000000‚Äô - they of course appear identical to us, but Python was treating those separate 0‚Äôs as in a ‚Äòdifferent‚Äô order) Anyway, after lots of Google and Stackoverflow, it turns out that there is a simple on liner, which actually is the itertools library, just using a not-so-commonly seen method, product():

lInvaders = ["".join(seq) for seq in itertools.product("10", repeat=15)] # all binary combinations of 0s and 1s and length 15

In the end, the total data generation script is only about 25 lines long:

import itertools
import collections  
import pandas as pd
import os
  
lInvaders = ["".join(seq) for seq in itertools.product('10', repeat=15)] # all binary combinations of 0s and 1s and length 15

# now we can see how many invaders have what rank (number of times '1' occurs in a given invader string)
lRanks = []
for i in range(0,len(lInvaders)):    
    lRanks.append(lInvaders[i].count('1'))

# put blocks string and rank into dataframe
oDataFrame = pd.DataFrame({'block_string': lInvaders, 'rank': lRanks})
oDataFrame = oDataFrame.sort_values(by=['rank'], ascending=True)
oDataFrame.to_json(os.getcwd() + '/data/all_data.json', orient='records')

# json for each rank
for i, x in oDataFrame.groupby('rank'):
    x.to_json(os.getcwd() + '/data/data_rank_{}.json'.format(i), orient='records')

# print for counts of each rank
# counter=collections.Counter(lRanks) 
# print(counter)

Frontend Fun

As it always seems to be with these fancy data algorithms, 99% of the ‚Äòmagic‚Äô to generate the Invaders happens in a double for loop. In the original Java code, it looks

for (int j=0;j<sz;j+=step) {
  m = 1;
  for (int i=0;i<sz/2;i+=step) {
    c = (random(1) > .5)? 255:0; //black or white?
    col[j][i]= c;
    col[j][i+(sz-step)/m] = c;
    m++;
  }
}
